subcategory: Lack of Executive Involvement in DEI Initiatives

content.text: This refers to the situation when the senior executives in the company are not supporting the DEI initiatives within an organization.
Executives fail to understand the importance of DEI due to a lack of available tools to measure its long-term impact.
Lack of women in top management positions negatively affects executive involvement in DEI.
A misconception exists among top leadership that a favorable and inclusive company culture exists in the organization.
There is a lack of accountability for the executive’s involvement in DEI initiatives.
Leaders have this assumption that they are already doing enough for DEI.

The involvement of leaders can be attained by encouraging leadership attendance at DEI events, highlighting DEI achievements within each leader's teams, and assisting leaders/executives in sponsoring a resource group.
Organizations need to increase the number of females in top management.
There needs to be an emphasis on how inactivity in this area might harm efforts to attract and retain talent.
Accountability metrics need to be implemented for top leadership.
There is a need to demonstrate to business leaders and executives how gender DEI positively impacts crucial business challenges.
